repnme.cdata!: Jordan - Second Public Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory;
            sustainability is likely. The overall performances of both
            the Bank and the Borrower are graded satisfactory. Lessons
            learned included the following: 1) Programmatic lending
            serves as a useful vehicle for economy-wide reforms. This
            instrument is particularly advantageous in structuring
            complex dialogue dealing with the whole government (and
            therefore across sectors), and in encouraging meaningful and
            precise progress over a well-defined time frame. Overcoming
            roadblocks, however, requires a frank and lucid evaluation
            of the Bank-country relationship-specifically, expectations
            of the durability and outcomes of the reform beyond the
            years considered under the program. 2) It is essential to
            develop monitoring and evaluation capacity-for evaluating
            both the progress of policies and programs underpinning the
            entire reform program. 3) A major part of the
            Government's analytical work (and Bank's Economic
            and Sector work) should focus on developing a
            performance-oriented budgeting system with a view to
            improving the efficiency of public expenditure management.
            4) Public Sector Reform Loans (PSRLs) are being implemented
            by several ministries and agencies, and requires overall
            coordination and monitoring. Here, coordination does not
            mean "command and control," rather ensuring
            long-term complementarity among the various components of
            the program. In this context, there is a need for creating a
            working group under the present inter-ministerial
            coordinating committee. This working group should be
            concerned with more than just monitoring and reporting; it
            should assure that the content of the various measures are
            aligned from the outset. Lastly, this working group should
            also be instrumental in setting up a process that allows the
            sharing and exchange of information and ideas. 5) For the
            program to achieve a substantive institutional development
            impact, it is important to interlink the various components
            of the program. To date, most of the progress has been
            achieved through pursuing parallel tracks. Now the reform
            program needs to focus on integrating the various elements
            (e.g., costing of government services, simplifying
            procedures, establishing a judicial information network). 6)
            PSRLs require a shift from an approach that focuses mostly
            on lending toward one that emphasizes policy dialogue
            underpinned by economic and sector work.

Jordan - Second Public Sector

repnme.cdata!: Jordan - Second Public Sector Reform Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Public Sector Reform Loan
            Project will contribute to the Government's growth
            promoting fiscal program, while external resources will
            reinforce the country's foreign reserve position, and
            underpin nominal exchange rate stability. Disbursements will
            be on the basis of satisfactory progress in the public
            sector management program, measured by actions improving the
            Government's institutional capacity, and incentives to
            deliver quality public services, as well as on the continued
            sound overall macroeconomic management. While the project
            will contribute in maintaining a stronger financial position
            to face economic, and political shocks, the continuing
            uncertainty in the Middle East could risk implementation of
            programs as described above. However, Jordan's past
            record demonstrates its strong, and sound economic, and
            political performance which far outweighs those risks.
            Moreover, the inherent long-term and comprehensive nature of
            public sector reforms, entails a slow implementation, whose
            fragmentation may jeopardize its coherency. Nonetheless, the
            appointment of an inter-ministerial steering committee, and
            the continued dialogue with the Bank, as well as other
            external partners, suggests the latter risk is manageable.
